title: Acute Traumatic Brain Injury Management
icd10: ** S06.9X0A (Unspecified intracranial injury without loss of consciousness
scope: ** Acute evaluation and management of traumatic brain injury in adults within the first 72 hours. Covers initial assessment (GCS, primary/secondary survey), neuroimaging decision rules, medical management of elevated ICP, seizure prophylaxis, coagulopathy reversal, non-surgical subdural/epidural management, and neurosurgical consultation criteria. Applies to ED, hospital, and ICU settings (acute phase — no outpatient). Excludes post-concussion syndrome (separate plan — chronic recovery phase), penetrating brain injury, pediatric TBI, and chronic subdural hematoma management.

Core Labs (Immediate).rationale: Baseline hemoglobin/hematocrit; thrombocytopenia increases hemorrhage risk; leukocytosis may indicate stress response or infection
Core Labs (Immediate).target: Platelets >100,000 for ICP monitor placement; Hgb >7 (>10 if active hemorrhage)

Core Labs (Immediate).rationale: Electrolytes (sodium critical for osmotherapy), glucose, renal function (mannitol safety), hepatic function (drug metabolism)
Core Labs (Immediate).target: Na 135-145 baseline; BUN/Cr for mannitol clearance; glucose 140-180

Core Labs (Immediate).target: INR <1.4 for ICP monitor/EVD placement; aPTT <40 sec

Core Labs (Immediate).rationale: DIC assessment in severe TBI; coagulopathy from tissue factor release
Core Labs (Immediate).target: Target >150 mg/dL; replace if <200 in active hemorrhage

Surgical candidacy; blood product availability; transfusion readiness
Core Labs (Immediate).target: Blood available within 30 min if needed

Core Labs (Immediate).target: Target 300-320 during osmotherapy; do NOT exceed 320

Core Labs (Immediate).target: Target 145-155 mEq/L during ICP crisis; avoid >160

Tissue perfusion marker; polytrauma assessment; occult shock detection
Confounds neurological exam; present in 30-50% of TBI patients; may explain altered mental status

Core Labs (Immediate).target: Elevated troponin → echocardiogram; rule out neurogenic stunned myocardium

Extended Labs.rationale: Monitor during osmotherapy to prevent renal injury and rebound cerebral edema
Track sodium correction during hypertonic saline; avoid overcorrection

Extended Labs.rationale: Pituitary injury screening; trauma-related hypopituitarism occurs in 30-40% severe TBI; adrenal insufficiency
Extended Labs.target: AM cortisol <10 mcg/dL suggests adrenal insufficiency → stimulation testing

Extended Labs.rationale: Pituitary injury screening; central hypothyroidism from hypothalamic-pituitary trauma
Extended Labs.target: Low free T4 with low/normal TSH suggests central hypothyroidism

Extended Labs.rationale: DIC screening in severe TBI; traumatic coagulopathy common
Extended Labs.target: Elevated → check fibrinogen, peripheral smear; trend with serial labs

Extended Labs.rationale: Infection surveillance; VAP, line infection, aspiration pneumonia common in ICU TBI patients
Extended Labs.target: Positive → targeted antibiotic therapy; assess for VAP if intubated

Extended Labs.rationale: Therapeutic drug monitoring if on phenytoin for seizure prophylaxis; narrow therapeutic index
Extended Labs.target: Target total 10-20 mcg/mL or free 1-2 mcg/mL; levetiracetam does NOT require monitoring

Specialized Labs.rationale: Functional coagulation assessment; identifies specific coagulation deficits; guides targeted blood product use in severe TBI
Specialized Labs.target: Guides platelet, FFP, cryoprecipitate, TXA use; more informative than standard coag panel

Specialized Labs.rationale: FDA-approved biomarkers to rule out CT-visible intracranial lesion in mild TBI (GCS 13-15); may reduce unnecessary CT
Specialized Labs.target: Negative predictive value >99% for CT-visible lesion; does NOT replace CT if clinically indicated

Specialized Labs.rationale: Culture, cell count, glucose, protein for infection surveillance; ventriculitis risk with EVD is 5-10%
Specialized Labs.target: WBC >5, low glucose, positive culture → ventriculitis; daily CSF sampling per protocol

Essential / First-line.timing: IMMEDIATE — within 30 minutes of arrival; any GCS <15, LOC, amnesia, vomiting, age >65, coagulopathy, dangerous mechanism (Canadian CT Head Rule / New Orleans Criteria)
Essential / First-line.target: Hemorrhage (SDH, EDH, SAH, contusion), midline shift (>5 mm = significant), cerebral edema, skull fracture, pneumocephalus
Essential / First-line.contraindications: None in acute trauma — benefit always outweighs radiation risk

Essential / First-line.timing: IMMEDIATE — assume concomitant c-spine injury until cleared; NEXUS or Canadian C-Spine Rule to determine need
Essential / First-line.target: Fracture, subluxation, ligamentous injury, prevertebral soft tissue swelling

Essential / First-line.timing: Within 1 hour if vascular injury suspected — Denver screening criteria: skull base fracture, cervical spine fracture, Horner syndrome, Le Fort II/III, neck soft tissue injury
Essential / First-line.target: Dissection, traumatic pseudoaneurysm, arteriovenous fistula, vessel occlusion
Essential / First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate if critical); renal insufficiency (benefit > risk in acute setting)

Essential / First-line.timing: Within 30 minutes — polytrauma assessment; confirm ETT position if intubated
Essential / First-line.target: Pneumothorax, hemothorax, rib fractures, aspiration, mediastinal widening, ETT placement verification

Extended (After Stabilization).timing: When hemodynamically stable — typically 24-72h; superior for DAI (SWI sequences), brainstem injury, petechial hemorrhages
Extended (After Stabilization).target: Diffuse axonal injury (microhemorrhages on SWI), brainstem lesions, cerebral edema extent, prognostic information
Extended (After Stabilization).contraindications: Unstable patient, non-MRI-compatible ICP monitor/EVD, ferromagnetic implants, hemodynamic instability

Extended (After Stabilization).timing: 6-8 hours after initial CT or immediately with any neurological change; 30% of traumatic SDH/EDH expand on repeat imaging
Extended (After Stabilization).target: Hemorrhage expansion, new hemorrhage, increased edema, evolving midline shift

Extended (After Stabilization).timing: If expanding hemorrhage, delayed neurological decline, or concern for vascular injury not previously assessed
Extended (After Stabilization).target: Vascular injury, pseudoaneurysm, active extravasation, vasospasm (traumatic SAH)
Extended (After Stabilization).contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal insufficiency (benefit > risk if clinically indicated)

Specialized.timing: Severe TBI (GCS ≤8) with abnormal CT; OR GCS ≤8 with normal CT if age >40, motor posturing, or SBP <90 (BTF guidelines)
Specialized.target: ICP >22 mmHg (BTF 4th edition threshold); guides osmotherapy, sedation, surgical decompression; EVD allows therapeutic CSF drainage
Specialized.contraindications: Coagulopathy (INR >1.4, platelets <100K — correct first); scalp infection at insertion site

Specialized.timing: If unexplained neurological decline, witnessed or suspected seizure, GCS does not improve as expected; subclinical seizures occur in 10-20% of severe TBI
Specialized.target: Non-convulsive seizures, non-convulsive status epilepticus, epileptiform discharges; guides antiepileptic therapy
Specialized.contraindications: None; critical for unexplained decline in TBI

Specialized.timing: Non-invasive ICP estimation; assess for cerebral vasospasm in traumatic SAH; serial monitoring
Specialized.target: Elevated mean flow velocities (vasospasm); pulsatility index correlates with ICP; loss of diastolic flow (critically elevated ICP)
Specialized.contraindications: Inadequate temporal bone window (10-15% of patients); operator dependent

Referrals.indication: ALL moderate-severe TBI; any subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma, depressed skull fracture; ICP monitoring candidacy; surgical decompression evaluation
Polytrauma; concomitant thoracic, abdominal, or orthopedic injuries
Orbital fractures; visual changes; fundoscopic exam for papilledema; retinal hemorrhages (non-accidental trauma screening)
Early rehabilitation consultation for moderate-severe TBI; functional prognosis assessment; discharge planning
Falls in elderly (home safety evaluation); assault (law enforcement, protective orders); domestic violence screening; substance abuse

Patient / Family Instructions.instructions: Return to ED immediately for: worsening headache not relieved by acetaminophen, repeated vomiting, increasing confusion or difficulty waking, seizure, unequal pupils, weakness on one side, clear fluid from nose or ears, slurred speech
Cognitive rest for 24-48 hours (limit screen time, reading, mental exertion); gradual return to activity as tolerated; no driving until symptom-free; follow-up with PCP or neurology in 1-2 weeks

Expect behavioral changes (irritability, impulsivity, emotional lability), sleep disturbance, headache, cognitive difficulties (memory, attention); recovery trajectory varies — most improvement in first 6-12 months; family support resources
Do NOT return to contact sports or activities with fall risk until completely symptom-free AND cleared by physician; second impact before recovery can cause fatal cerebral edema
